text: (upbeat music)
- At Deepsea, we've developed a solution
that enables the maritime industry
to understand and optimize

the performance and environmental
impact of their vessels.
We gather real-time data about vessels
from all available sources,
including from aboard the vessel itself,
using hardware that we produce.

The data is stored and
analyzed on the cloud,
where it's used to train individual
vessel-specific machine learning models,

which we use to deliver
insights to our customers,
including when to clean the vessel,

what speeds and paths
to take for every route,

as well as alerting
them to various problems
during the vessel operations.
We're a team of 65 people and growing,
with operations in every continent,
tracking vessels in every ocean.

Our vision is to make
the world of shipping
greener, leaner, and better connected

by learning every vessel
deeper and more completely.
Our primary motivation for moving
to the cloud was scalability.
As our sales increased exponentially
and we needed to add an increasing number
of vessels into our system,

we needed a solution
that allowed our storage,
and processing to scale seamlessly.
Before AWS, we ran all our workloads
and applications on Bare Metals.

This meant that we had time
and cost expensive devops
and hardware maintenance operations
that couldn't scale as needed
as we added more data into our system.
It was also difficult for us to be able
to back up our data robustly and securely.
The need for dedicated hardware
also made our compute use inefficient,
particularly when it came to using GPU's

for deep learning
training and evaluations.
With AWS, we now have an infrastructure
that's easy to deploy and use.

Manage services allow us
an efficient and secure way
to backup our data.
Using Infrastructure's code tools,

we're able to optimize
our use of resources
in a way that previously was not possible.
We use EC2 to run our data processing

and machine learning
workloads in Java and Python.
We use RDS and S3 for storage.
We've also found particularly useful MSK,

which we use to run Kafka for
our Steam processing needs.

Our chief objective of
being able to rapidly

and seamlessly scale our
services has been met.

We now have over 10 billion
data points in our system,

corresponding to 150 years
of combined traveling data,
and this is expected to increase six fold
by the end of the year.

We're now able to transfer
hundreds of gigabytes of data
between production environments
seamlessly within a few minutes,

AWS has allowed us to
eliminate many time consuming
hardware maintenance and dev ops tasks.

We appreciated the transparency
of AWS's customer service,

being able to talk to
the company directly.
And in particular, we were very happy

with the way they engaged with
us as an early stage startup

and were able to adapt to
our needs at that phase.
(upbeat music)
